rationales.tradition: He plans to miss Sunday family time with his mother because paid bookings take precedence.
rationales.security: His decision is driven by income preservation in a precarious gig-work context.

rationales.tradition: He explicitly values lived, inherited forms of warmth and community over curated simulations of them.

rationales.benevolence: He stops to share coffee and companionship with an isolated older customer despite platform penalties.
rationales.tradition: He interprets that choice through family-taught norms of neighborly duty and relational presence.
rationales.conformity: He knowingly violates app timing expectations and accepts a warning.

rationales.tradition: He misses Koningsdag family rituals for extra bookings and then regrets the absence.
rationales.security: He explicitly takes the workday because he needs the money.

rationales.tradition: Time at his mother's home reconnects him to long-standing family routines and memories.
rationales.security: He experiences that familiar setting as stabilizing and physically restorative.

rationales.tradition: He actively reflects on shared family/church rhythms and what it would take for his own rituals to carry communal meaning.
He preserves a faith practice (saying grace) in a mixed family setting because it matters across generations.
rationales.benevolence: He honors his son's request and emotional connection to family memory.

rationales.power: He highlights having no bargaining leverage as platforms unilaterally change terms.
rationales.security: Lower base rates and unstable algorithmic pay make his livelihood less predictable.

rationales.tradition: He intentionally reconnects with church, family pew, and inherited language as enduring identity anchors.
rationales.security: He uses those enduring anchors to regain a sense of steadiness amid volatile work conditions.
